issues.description: The problem statement (UML and textual description) specifies a method getTotalNumberOfStudents() with no parameters that returns the total number of students. The solution implementation instead defines getTotalNumberOfStudents(boolean includeGuests) which requires a boolean parameter. This parameter mismatch contradicts the specified method signature in the exercise and will confuse students (and break any tests) that expect a no-argument method as described in the problem statement and UML.
issues.suggested_fix: Make the solution match the problem specification by providing a no-argument method: public int getTotalNumberOfStudents() that returns the total number of students (inscribed + guest). Update dependent methods in the solution (e.g. getNameAndTotalNumberOfStudents(), getNumberOfStudentsPerTutor()) to call this no-arg method. Alternatively, if the boolean parameter is intended, update the problem statement and UML to specify getTotalNumberOfStudents(boolean includeGuests) and explain the parameter's meaning. Adding an overloaded no-arg method that calls the boolean variant (or vice versa) is another acceptable fix to preserve backward compatibility.

issues.description: The problem statement (UML and textual tasks) specifies a no-argument method getTotalNumberOfStudents(): int, but the solution implements getTotalNumberOfStudents(boolean includeGuests). This changes the method signature and the expected usage: students reading the problem will look for a no-arg method that returns the total number of students, while the solution requires a boolean parameter to include guest students. This mismatch breaks the one-to-one mapping between the described requirement and the reference implementation and will confuse students (and automated tests) about the correct method to implement and call.
issues.suggested_fix: Align the solution and template with the problem statement. Either (A) change the solution method to the expected no-argument signature and behavior: public int getTotalNumberOfStudents() { return numberOfInscribedStudents + numberOfGuestStudents; } and update any internal calls (e.g., getNumberOfStudentsPerTutor(), getNameAndTotalNumberOfStudents()) to use this no-arg method; or (B) if the boolean parameter is intentional, update the problem statement and UML to declare getTotalNumberOfStudents(boolean includeGuests): int and explain the parameter meaning so students can map the requirement to the implementation. Option (A) is recommended to preserve the stated exercise API and avoid unnecessary cognitive overhead.
